## Clinical History
A 43-year-old female presents with a six-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and wheezing. She denies cough, fevers, chills, or weight loss. She has no history of chronic illnesses or tobacco use.

## Physical Exam
The physical examination revealed no abnormalities.

## Imaging Findings
Axial CT images of the chest demonstrate nodular and branching opacities in the right upper lobe, consistent with a tree-in-bud pattern. A large, well-circumscribed mass is present in the left lower lobe. Additionally, there is evidence of interstitial changes in the right lung, including honeycombing and pleural thickening, particularly in the right lower lobe, along with a small right-sided pleural effusion.

## Assessment & Plan
Laboratory analysis of fungal, acid-fast, and Gram stains showed no organisms. Pleural fluid analysis was suspicious for malignancy. Histopathologic analysis of tissue from all three right lung lobes and mediastinal lymph nodes confirmed malignancy, showing extensive lymphovascular invasion, focal necrosis, and signet-ring cells.

## Demographics
The patient is a 43-year-old female.

## Missing Info
Information not provided includes cancer stage, performance status, and prior treatment history.

## Clinical History
A 47-year-old male presented in November 2005 with right anterior thigh pain. An X-ray showed a mass in the femur and adjacent soft tissue, which on partial resection was identified as adenocarcinoma. A subsequent PET scan revealed increased uptake in the right lung, where a history of stable pulmonary nodules existed since 2003. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic adenocarcinoma of the right lung. Past medical history is significant for nephrolithiasis and hyperlipidemia. Past surgical history includes a benign right neck lymph node resection and a cholecystectomy. The patient has a 20-year smoking history of over one pack per day. There is a strong family history of cancer, with three sisters dying of lung cancer and a brother diagnosed with head and neck cancer.

## Physical Exam
Physical examination findings were not provided in the clinical notes.

## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of axial CT images reveals a large, irregular soft tissue mass in the posterior aspect of the right lower lobe, appearing pleural-based with associated right hilar adenopathy. An additional large, heterogeneous soft tissue mass is present within the right gluteal musculature. A possible low-density lesion is noted in the right adrenal gland. The provided EHR text notes progression of these findings over time, as well as rib destruction, endobronchial narrowing, and mesenteric masses.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with metastatic adenocarcinoma of the right lung. The plan was for the patient to undergo radiation and chemotherapy under the care of oncology.

## Demographics
The patient is a 47-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Physical exam findings were not available. Specific details regarding the chemotherapy and radiation regimens are not provided.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 67-year-old male presented for evaluation of an abnormal chest radiograph, which was discovered during a workup for recent hepatic and left kidney abscesses.

## Physical Exam
Findings on physical examination include tenderness over the left apical chest, dyspnea, and a chronic cough.

## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of the provided axial CT images reveals a large, destructive mass in the left lung apex with extensive invasion into the adjacent chest wall, posterior ribs, and vertebral bodies. Multiple additional nodules are present in the left lung, with at least one contralateral nodule in the right lung. Mediastinal and hilar adenopathy is also noted. An upper abdominal slice shows a mass in the left kidney and an enlarged right adrenal gland.

## Assessment & Plan
A transbronchial biopsy confirmed a diagnosis of Non-Small Cell Carcinoma. The imaging and clinical findings are consistent with advanced, metastatic disease involving bone, contralateral lung, lymph nodes, and adrenal and renal sites.

## Demographics
The patient is a 67-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Specific TNM staging, patient's performance status (e.g., ECOG score), smoking history, and details of prior treatment for abscesses are not provided.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
An 86-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, hypothyroidism, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, dementia, and depression was transferred from his assisted living facility for a three-week history of decreased oral intake, dry cough, increased confusion, and recent hypotension. He was admitted for bilateral pneumonia and malnutrition.

## Physical Exam
The patient is an 86-year-old, well-developed but poorly nourished male with dementia, who is a poor historian. He complains of cough and poor appetite. Pulmonary exam reveals bilateral rales and rhonchi. The cardiovascular exam is notable for an irregular rate and rhythm. His skin is pale, warm, and dry. The abdomen is non-tender and non-distended with positive bowel sounds. Extremities are without edema.

## Imaging Findings
Axial CT of the chest demonstrates extensive bilateral pulmonary abnormalities. There are numerous, variably sized nodules and areas of consolidation throughout both lungs, more prominent on the right. These findings are superimposed on a background of severe fibrotic changes, including reticulation, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing, particularly in the lower lobes, consistent with a usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. The combination is suggestive of metastatic disease in the setting of underlying idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient is an 86-year-old male with multiple comorbidities, including idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, admitted for pneumonia and malnutrition. Labs were significant for leukocytosis (WBC 17.7) and hypoalbuminemia (Alb 2.8). Blood cultures were negative, but a respiratory culture grew Candida. A bronchoscopy confirmed a new diagnosis of metastatic Squamous Cell Non-small Cell Lung Cancer.

## Demographics
The patient is an 86-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Information not available in the provided record includes smoking history, cancer stage, and performance status (e.g., ECOG).

## Physical Exam
Respiratory exam reveals the right side is clear to auscultation, while the left side has decreased breath sounds and egophany over the lower portion of the lung. Cardiovascular exam shows a regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Extremities show no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. ## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of the provided axial CT image of the chest reveals a large, irregular mass in the left upper lobe with features suggestive of central necrosis or cavitation. The mass abuts the mediastinum, including the aortic arch. There is an associated moderate-sized left-sided pleural effusion. The trachea appears to be slightly deviated to the right.

## Clinical History
A 76-year-old man with a known history of primary lung cancer was referred for a 3-phase contrast-enhanced abdominal CT to further evaluate a liver lesion identified on a prior study.

## Physical Exam
No physical examination findings were provided in the clinical notes.

## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of the provided axial contrast-enhanced CT images of the abdomen reveals a large, well-defined, round lesion in the right posterior lobe of the liver. The lesion demonstrates a hypodense, necrotic-appearing center with a distinct, peripherally enhancing rim, a finding highly suggestive of a metastatic deposit. The accompanying text also notes two masses in the left lower lobe of the lung, which are not visualized on these abdominal images.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient has a known primary lung cancer with a new liver lesion suspicious for metastasis. The diagnostic plan included the contrast-enhanced CT for characterization, followed by an ultrasound-guided needle biopsy of the liver lesion for histopathological confirmation.

## Demographics
The patient is a 76-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Physical exam findings, results of the liver biopsy, and details of the primary lung cancer staging were not provided.

## Clinical History
A 59-year-old woman presents with facial swelling and breast discomfort, which are worse in the morning and when lying flat. She also reports worsening orthopnea.

## Physical Exam
Vital signs show a blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg, heart rate of 106 bpm, respiratory rate of 18, and oxygen saturation of 90% on 2-4 L nasal cannula. The patient is alert and oriented. Significant findings include extensive jugular venous distention (JVD) while upright, coarse breath sounds bilaterally, and enlarged breasts.

## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of the provided axial and coronal CT images reveals a large mass in the right upper lobe with significant mediastinal mass effect. A large, dense right-sided pleural effusion is present, causing near-complete opacification of the right hemithorax and elevation of the right hemidiaphragm. Bilateral breast enlargement is also noted.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient's presentation with facial swelling, JVD, and a right upper lobe mass is highly suggestive of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome, likely secondary to malignancy. The provided text does not include a formal assessment or plan.

## Demographics
The patient is a 59-year-old woman.

## Missing Info
Information regarding the patient's formal assessment and treatment plan is not available in the provided text.

## Clinical History
A 59-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of right lung non-small cell lung cancer presents with severe hemoptysis.

## Physical Exam
The patient exhibits severe cachexia, hemodynamic instability, respiratory distress, and has a falling hematocrit.

## Imaging Findings
A contrast-enhanced axial CT image of the chest reveals a large, high-density consolidation in the right lung. Within this consolidation, there is a brightly enhancing focus consistent with a pseudoaneurysm of a right pulmonary artery branch. There is also evidence of hemorrhage into the surrounding lung parenchyma. The left lung appears clear. The provided imaging window does not allow for clear differentiation between tumor and hemorrhagic consolidation.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient's severe hemoptysis is attributed to a pseudoaneurysm of a right pulmonary artery branch in the context of his lung cancer. The plan involved endovascular intervention, and after coiling of the pseudoaneurysm, no further flow was noted within it.

## Demographics
The patient is a 59-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Specific cancer staging, detailed lab values, and vital signs were not provided in the source text.

## Clinical History
The patient has a prior history of a left paraganglioma located at the carotid bifurcation. A recent MRI suggested a recurrence of the tumor.

## Physical Exam
The physical exam was non-contributory.

## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of the provided axial and coronal MRI images of the neck reveals a lobulated, enhancing mass in the left neck, consistent with a recurrent tumor at the carotid bifurcation. The EHR text further describes this as a mass with intermediate T1 signal, high T2 signal, and enhancement. A coregistered SPECT/CT scan using In-111-octreotide confirmed a focus of increased radiotracer uptake in the same location, confirming recurrence.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient is diagnosed with a recurrence of their known paraganglioma. The treatment plan is not specified.

## Demographics
Patient age and sex are not provided in the source material.

Other significant past medical history includes a stroke in 1988 with residual dysarthria, impaired cognition, and abnormal gait. Comorbidities include hyperlipidemia, chronic congestive heart failure, diabetes, and hypertension. The patient received chemotherapy with Cisplatin and Paclitaxel for the lung cancer. Other medications include Simvastatin, Furosemide, Metformin, Lisinopril, and Insulin.

## Physical Exam
No detailed physical examination findings are provided in the record. Laboratory observations from September 1993 include a body weight of 104.9 kg, an elevated NT-proBNP of 1137.4 pg/mL, and blood counts within relatively normal limits (Leukocytes 9.8 10*3/uL, Erythrocytes 4.1 10*6/uL, Hemoglobin 11.4 g/dL).

## Imaging Findings
Direct analysis of the provided chest X-ray reveals a large, irregular, spiculated mass in the right upper lobe, highly suspicious for a primary lung malignancy. The cardiac silhouette appears mildly enlarged. No definite large pleural effusion or pneumothorax is identified.

The patient was diagnosed with Non-small cell carcinoma of the lung, TNM stage 1, and was undergoing treatment with chemotherapy (Cisplatin and Paclitaxel). ## Clinical History
A 66-year-old male presented with a two-week history of back pain and cough. He was admitted on August 8, 2019. The patient has a 40-year smoking history and worked as a farmer, with long-term exposure to chemicals like pesticides and fertilizers. Genetic testing revealed an EGFR exon 19 somatic mutation and a TP53 germline mutation. Based on blood tests, bone marrow aspiration, and copy number variation analysis (whole chromosome 7 and 5q deletion), he was also diagnosed with secondary Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS).

## Physical Exam
Physical examination findings were not provided in the source text.

## Imaging Findings
A thoracic CT scan on August 25, 2019, showed a malignant tumor in the left upper lobe with distal obstructive inflammation. The scan also revealed enlarged left hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes and multiple bone metastases.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with stage IVb lung adenocarcinoma with bone metastases, as well as secondary MDS. Biopsy of the bronchial mucosa confirmed adenocarcinoma based on histopathology and positive IHC staining for TTF1, CK7, and NapsinA. A 733-gene NGS panel was performed to identify potential therapeutic targets. The provided text cuts off before detailing the treatment plan.

## Demographics
The patient is a 66-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Information regarding the patient's physical exam findings and specific treatment plan is missing from the provided text.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 59-year-old man, an ex-smoker with a 45 pack-year history, was diagnosed with stage I (pT2, pN0) lung adenocarcinoma in July 2008 and treated with an upper right lung lobectomy. In July 2020, a recurrence was identified, involving three new lesions in the left lung. The patient underwent wedge resections of these lesions in August 2020. Histopathology revealed one lesion to be a combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid, and the other two to be pulmonary adenocarcinomas with varying molecular profiles.

## Physical Exam
No physical examination findings were provided in the source text.

## Imaging Findings
A chest CT scan in July 2020 revealed the presence of one lesion in the upper left lung lobe and two lesions in the lower left lung lobe.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient has a history of resected stage I lung adenocarcinoma with a 2020 diagnosis of synchronous primary lung cancers, staged as pT4 (m-3) (PL0) pN0. The three left lung lesions included a combined adenocarcinoma/atypical carcinoid (ALK/ROS1 negative, PD-L1 <1%), a ROS1-positive pulmonary adenocarcinoma (PD-L1 1-49%), and an ALK/ROS1-negative pulmonary adenocarcinoma (PD-L1 >50%). The plan involved surgical resection of all three lesions via wedge resection, followed by comprehensive molecular analysis using NGS.

## Demographics
The patient is a male who was 59 years old at the time of his initial diagnosis in 2008.

## Missing Info
Information on the patient's physical exam is missing.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 65-year-old female was diagnosed in 2017 with stage IIA non-small cell adenocarcinoma of the right middle lobe. She underwent a right middle lobectomy and mediastinal node dissection, followed by adjuvant carboplatin/Alimta chemotherapy. In January 2019, a relapse was detected with multiple nodular masses in the right lower lobe. She received palliative chemotherapy (carboplatin, taxol, and pembrolizumab) followed by pembrolizumab maintenance. The nodules resolved by October 2019. In March 2020, she developed acute kidney injury with a rising creatinine level, which was diagnosed via biopsy as acute and chronic interstitial nephritis. Pembrolizumab was held and she was treated with prednisone, leading to improvement in renal function. An attempt to resume pembrolizumab resulted in a recurrence of the kidney injury, leading to its permanent discontinuation. The patient expired a few months after September 2020.

## Physical Exam
The patient was noted to be asymptomatic with no lower extremities edema when her creatinine level began to rise.

## Imaging Findings
A chest CT in 2017 identified the primary non-small cell adenocarcinoma of the right middle lobe. A repeat chest CT in January 2019 showed multiple nodular masses in the right lower lobe, and a PET/CT scan confirmed subpleural nodules with moderate FDG activity, indicating relapse. A subsequent CT in May 2019 showed a decrease in the size of these nodules. By October 2019, a chest CT showed complete resolution of the pulmonary nodules.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient had a history of stage IIA NSCLC, treated with surgery and adjuvant chemotherapy, which later relapsed. The relapse was treated with combination chemotherapy and immunotherapy, followed by maintenance immunotherapy, which led to a complete response. However, she developed a significant adverse event, pembrolizumab-induced interstitial nephritis, requiring cessation of the immunotherapy and treatment with steroids. The decision was made to stop pembrolizumab indefinitely due to the recurrence of kidney injury upon re-challenge.

## Demographics
The patient is a 65-year-old female.

## Missing Info
No missing information for required fields was identified.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 19-year-old female was diagnosed with histiocytic sarcoma in December 2017 after presenting with a two-month history of pharyngeal pain, a left neck mass, and fever. She required a tracheotomy due to airway obstruction from a large parapharyngeal mass. Initial treatment with CHOEP chemotherapy was ineffective. Next-generation sequencing revealed MET exon 14 and MAP2K1 mutations. She was subsequently treated with radiotherapy (total 60 Gy/30 F) and the MET inhibitor crizotinib, which resulted in a partial response. Crizotinib was discontinued after two months due to financial reasons, prompting a search for new therapeutic targets via further NGS.

## Physical Exam
The patient presented with a left neck mass and a large mass in the left parapharyngeal space, causing airway obstruction, pharyngeal pain, and dysphagia. She also experienced fever.

## Imaging Findings
A PET/CT scan revealed a large solid mass in the left parapharyngeal space compressing the pharyngeal cavity, along with multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. After 20 Gy of irradiation, the pharyngeal mass reduced from 6.0 cm x 4.4 cm to 5.6 cm x 4.0 cm, and the neck mass from 3.5 cm x 2.8 cm to 2.9 cm x 2.6 cm. After a full course of radiotherapy and one month of crizotinib, the sum of the product of the longest perpendicular dimensions (SPD) decreased by 57%.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient has histiocytic sarcoma with MET exon 14 and MAP2K1 mutations, which showed a partial response to radiotherapy and crizotinib after failing initial chemotherapy. Due to the high cost of crizotinib, the treatment was stopped. The plan is to perform further next-generation sequencing to identify new targetable therapeutic options.

## Demographics
The patient is a 19-year-old female.

## Missing Info
Race, ethnicity, and specific dates for most clinical events are not provided in the text.

## Clinical History
A 65-year-old male, a former smoker with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, presented with a 15-day history of a continuous irritable cough. He was admitted for a mass lesion in the right hilum. A bronchoscopy revealed a tumor occluding the right upper lobar bronchus and infiltrating the bronchus intermedius, which was diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma via biopsy. The patient also had a coincidental diagnosis of persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC).

## Physical Exam
The patient is a 65-year-old male. On presentation, he had no facial swelling or superficial varicose veins.

## Imaging Findings
Chest contrast CT showed an 80 mm mass in the right upper lobe, directly invading the arch of the right pulmonary artery and a wide range of the superior vena cava (SVC). Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a dilated coronary sinus (21 mm) and findings consistent with a persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC). Brain MRI, upper abdomen CT, and a bone scan showed no detectable distant metastases. A post-treatment chest MRI confirmed the patency of a vascular graft and the PLSVC.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right lung with invasion of the SVC and right pulmonary artery, and positive mediastinal lymph nodes. He underwent a right posterolateral thoracotomy with a double sleeve lobectomy of the right upper and middle lobes, along with SVC and pulmonary artery reconstruction using a PTFE graft. Postoperatively, he received anticoagulation, 4 cycles of chemotherapy (Gemcitabine and cisplatin), and 1 cycle of radiotherapy. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, but he died 21 months after the operation due to remote metastasis.

## Demographics
The patient is a 65-year-old male.

## Missing Info
All required information was available in the provided text.

## Clinical History
A 64-year-old man with a history of micropapillary thyroid cancer and stage IIIb EGFR-positive lung adenocarcinoma (stable for 3 years) presented with new fatigue, nausea, scalp tenderness, and xeroderma. Initial workup revealed a pituitary mass and lab findings consistent with panhypopituitarism, including low cortisol, testosterone, and LH, with elevated prolactin. He was started on steroid replacement. Within a month, he developed acute bilateral visual field cuts and loss of peripheral vision, corresponding to a rapid enlargement of the pituitary mass.

## Physical Exam
On examination, vital signs were within normal limits. Xeroderma was noted on all extremities. There were no signs of prognathism, acromegaly, or Cushingoid features. The cardiopulmonary exam was normal.

## Imaging Findings
An initial screening MRI of the head revealed a new hypovascular pituitary mass measuring approximately 1 cm by 0.8 cm. A repeat MRI one month later, following acute visual changes, demonstrated rapid enlargement of the mass to 2.2 cm by 1.2 cm, with impingement on the overlying optic chiasm.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with a pituitary mass, later confirmed by pathology after transsphenoidal resection to be metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. The histology revealed a new EGFR T790M mutation in addition to the previously known L858R mutation. His lab results indicated adrenal insufficiency and hypogonadism, for which he was started on hydrocortisone replacement therapy. Following surgery, he underwent whole-brain radiation.

## Demographics
The patient is a 64-year-old man.

## Missing Info
All required information was available in the provided text.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 56-year-old woman with unresectable Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC), stage pT3N0M0, was treated with nivolumab after progressing on adjuvant cisplatin-pemetrexed. After 5 infusions of nivolumab, she developed skin lesions, and after 20 infusions, she developed enlarging mediastinal nodes and a micronodular interstitial syndrome. Biopsies and mediastinoscopy confirmed a sarcoid-like reaction (SLR) with no evidence of tumor, infection, or foreign bodies. Nivolumab was discontinued. Despite the SLR, the patient had a partial response to treatment for her NSCLC per RECIST criteria.

## Physical Exam
The patient is a 56-year-old female. Skin lesions appeared after 5 nivolumab infusions and decreased 155 days after discontinuation of the drug.

## Imaging Findings
A CT scan after 5 nivolumab infusions suggested a partial response. After 20 infusions, imaging showed an increase in mediastinal node size and a micronodular interstitial syndrome. A follow-up CT scan 348 days after stopping nivolumab showed normal mediastinal nodes and regression of the interstitial syndrome.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient has unresectable NSCLC with a partial response to nivolumab. However, she developed a significant immune-related adverse event in the form of a sarcoid-like reaction, which led to the discontinuation of nivolumab. The SLR involved the skin, mediastinal lymph nodes, and lungs. The plan involved stopping immunotherapy, after which the SLR showed gradual resolution over several months. The patient's immune profile (PD-1/PD-L1 expression) was monitored after treatment cessation.

## Demographics
- Age: 56 years
- Sex: Female

## Missing Info
- Race/ethnicity
- Performance status
- Specific dates of treatment initiation and discontinuation
- Full details of prior chemotherapy regimen and response

## Clinical History
A 54-year-old male presented with a three-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a six-month history of intermittent cough with yellowish sputum and dyspnoea on exertion. His past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension and a smoking history of one pack per day. His family history is notable for lung adenocarcinoma. He recently traveled to Yunnan, China. An initial course of oral azithromycin for suspected infiltration on chest X-ray was ineffective.

## Physical Exam
Physical examination was unremarkable except for fine crackles over bilateral lung fields on chest auscultation. The patient was afebrile with a smooth respiratory pattern. Peripheral capillary oxygen saturation (SpO2) was 95% on ambient air.

## Imaging Findings
Initial chest X-ray demonstrated increased infiltration over bilateral lung fields, later described as diffuse interstitial infiltration. A subsequent chest CT revealed extensive patchy ground-glass opacities with thickened interlobular septa and intralobular lines, creating a “crazy paving” pattern. A radial probe endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) showed a “blizzard sign,” suggestive of ground-glass opacity in the right lower lobe.

## Assessment & Plan
Workup for respiratory decline revealed normal white blood cell count and negative autoimmune markers. Sputum cultures and PCR were negative for common pathogens, including Pneumocystis jiroveci. Pulmonary function tests showed normal spirometry but a moderately reduced DLCO (57.7% of predicted). Bronchoscopy with BAL, brush cytology, and biopsies (forceps and cryobiopsy) was performed for further investigation. Microbiological analysis of the BAL was negative. The patient is awaiting the final pathological diagnosis from the biopsy specimens.

## Demographics
The patient is a 54-year-old male.

## Missing Info
The definitive primary diagnosis is not available as the pathological report from the biopsy is not included in the provided text.

## Clinical History
An 81-year-old male was diagnosed with untreatable stage IIIA lung adenocarcinoma without mutation. Initial treatment included surgery, radiotherapy, and adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and pemetrexed. Four months later, he experienced local recurrence, which was irradiated without response. He then received palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel but showed disease progression. Subsequently, he started immunotherapy with pembrolizumab. After four cycles, he developed dyspnea, dry cough, and an oxygen saturation of 80%. He was found to have leukocytosis and extensive bilateral pulmonary infiltration on chest tomography. He was treated with corticosteroids and antibiotics, leading to significant clinical improvement.

## Physical Exam
The patient presented with dyspnea, dry cough, and an oxygen saturation of 80%. He is an 81-year-old male.

## Imaging Findings
Chest tomography revealed extensive bilateral pulmonary infiltration. A subsequent controlled computed tomography showed resolution of these findings after treatment.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient is an 81-year-old male with recurrent and progressive stage IIIA lung adenocarcinoma who developed a severe adverse reaction, likely pneumonitis, to pembrolizumab. This condition was characterized by respiratory symptoms, hypoxemia, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. The plan involved initiating corticosteroid and antibiotic therapy, which resulted in significant clinical and radiological improvement.

## Demographics
The patient is an 81-year-old male.

## Missing Info
Specific dates of treatment and recurrence, as well as detailed laboratory values beyond leukocytosis, were not provided. No lung biopsy was performed to confirm the pathology of the pulmonary infiltrates.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 30-year-old female presented with a two-month history of excruciating low back pain and generalized body ache, particularly at night, which was not relieved by simple analgesics. She also reported a poor appetite and a weight loss of 4-5 kg over three months. She is a nonsmoker with no significant past medical history or pulmonary symptoms.

## Physical Exam
Physical examination revealed bilateral discrete, small cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The breast examination was normal, and other systemic examinations were not significant.

## Imaging Findings
A chest X-ray showed bilateral fluffy hilar opacities. A subsequent CT of the thorax revealed scattered multifocal consolidation in the left lung, scattered mosaic perfusion in the subpleural region, small nodules in the right lung, and prominent hila. The bone window identified multiple variable-sized sclerotic bony lesions in the vertebrae without collapse or spinal canal stenosis. An ultrasound of the neck confirmed bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. A whole-body PET scan demonstrated progressing pulmonary consolidations and nodules, multiple osseous involvements, generalized metabolically active lymphadenopathy (supra- and infradiaphragmatic), and hepatomegaly with a solitary hepatic lesion. A follow-up PET scan after 7 months of treatment showed a favorable response with metabolic resolution of lung, lymph node, and bone metastases.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma, confirmed by an axillary lymph node biopsy with immunohistochemistry positive for Napsin A and negative for GATA-3, consistent with a lung primary. She was started on chemotherapy with crizotinib and denosumab, showing a good response on a follow-up PET scan.

## Demographics
The patient is a 30-year-old female.

## Missing Info
All required information was available in the provided text.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 59-year-old man with a history of stage T1A non-small cell lung cancer (large cell carcinoma) of the right upper lobe, treated with SBRT two years prior, presented with an eight-week history of nausea, abdominal pain, and a 20-lbs weight loss. His surveillance imaging since treatment had been negative.

## Physical Exam
No physical examination findings were provided in the source text.

## Imaging Findings
A total body PET-CT revealed thickening of the gastric fundus wall, a mass in the tail of the pancreas, both with increased radiotracer uptake, and a 1.1-cm filling defect in the splenic vein consistent with a thrombus. An upper endoscopy showed a 5-cm infiltrative and ulcerated mass in the gastric fundus. An endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) identified a 26 mm × 23 mm hypoechoic mass in the pancreatic tail with local vascular involvement and confirmed the splenic vein thrombus.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with two synchronous primary cancers. A gastric biopsy indicated poorly differentiated carcinoma, suggestive of metastasis from his known lung primary (TTF1 positive). However, an EUS-guided biopsy of the pancreatic mass confirmed a separate primary pancreatic neuroendocrine carcinoma (synaptophysin, chromogranin, and CDX-2 positive; TTF1 negative). After discussion, the patient opted for palliative care and symptomatic treatment.

## Demographics
The patient is a 59-year-old man.

## Missing Info
- Physical Exam

This confirmed neuroendocrine carcinoma (positive synaptophysin and chromogranin, positive Ki-67 and CDX-2, negative TTF1) (Figure ). Findings were suggestive of synchronous primary pancreatic neuroendocrine carcinoma.

## Clinical History
A 76-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis was found to have a small nodule in the left upper lobe (S1+2) on a checkup CT scan. A follow-up CT one year later showed the nodule had grown to 22 mm with indentation. Subsequent workup including FDG-PET, brain MRI, and transbronchial biopsy led to a diagnosis of left upper lung adenocarcinoma, staged as cT1bN0M0 Stage IA. The patient had renal dysfunction, which precluded a preoperative contrast-enhanced 3D CT angiography. She underwent a video-assisted thoracoscopic left upper lobectomy and lymphadenectomy. An abnormal pulmonary mediastinal branch from the left main pulmonary artery was identified intraoperatively.

## Physical Exam
The patient is a 76-year-old female.

## Imaging Findings
An initial CT scan detected a small nodule in the left upper lobe (S1+2). A follow-up CT one year later demonstrated growth of the nodule to 22 mm with associated indentation. FDG-PET and brain MRI were performed, but specific findings are not detailed. A contrast-enhanced 3D CT angiography was not performed due to renal dysfunction. Retrospective review of a non-contrast CT confirmed the presence of an anomalous pulmonary mediastinal branch (A8) from the left main pulmonary artery.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient was diagnosed with left upper lung adenocarcinoma, cT1bN0M0, Stage IA. The plan was surgical resection, and she underwent a video-assisted thoracoscopic left upper lobectomy with lymphadenectomy.

## Demographics
The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis.

## Missing Info
Specific findings from the FDG-PET and brain MRI were not provided.

profiles.profile_text:
## Clinical History
A 63-year-old Japanese man with a greater than 45 pack-year smoking history was found to have an abnormal shadow in the left middle lung field on a routine chest X-ray. His past medical history was unremarkable. A trans-bronchial lung biopsy of the mass, located in the left upper lobe, revealed non-small cell carcinoma. His serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was elevated at 52.1 ng/mL. The preoperative clinical diagnosis was primary lung cancer, stage cT2aN0M0 (Stage IB).

## Physical Exam
No physical examination findings were mentioned in the provided text.

## Imaging Findings
A chest X-ray revealed an abnormal shadow in the left middle lung field. A subsequent chest CT scan showed a 3.6 × 2.8 cm pulmonary lesion in the left upper lobe with a clear boundary and heterogeneous contrast enhancement. A PET scan demonstrated FDG accumulation in the nodule with an SUV max of 4.95 in the early phase and 6.31 in the late phase. No FDG accumulation was observed in the pulmonary hilum or mediastinal lymph nodes.

## Assessment & Plan
The patient underwent a left upper lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node dissection. The final histopathological diagnosis was H-FLAC. Pathological examination revealed a resected tumor size of 3.8 × 2.8 × 2.8 cm, with lymphatic and vascular invasion present. Metastasis was found in mediastinal lymph nodes (#5), leading to a final pathological staging of pT2aN2M0 (Stage IIIA). Biomarker testing was negative for EGFR mutations, ALK gene rearrangements, and PD-L1 expression. The patient received two courses of adjuvant chemotherapy (cisplatin plus vinorelbine), which was discontinued due to side effects. He experienced a relapse with pleural dissemination 25 months after surgery.

## Demographics
The patient is a 63-year-old Japanese man.

## Missing Info
All required fields were populated from the provided text.
